subtitle.en-US: Nourishing breakfast to warm your center

text.en-US: Bring 4 cups water to a boil
Add 1/2 cup rice and 2 slices fresh ginger
Reduce heat and simmer, stirring occasionally
Add salt to taste and top with scallions
Eat slowly, savoring the warmth

one_line.en-US: Congee is easily digestible and warming to the center.

plain.en-US: The long cooking breaks down the rice, making nutrients readily available. Ginger adds warming properties that support digestion.

tcm.en-US: Congee supports the Spleen and Stomach, which are responsible for transforming food into usable energy (Qi). Morning warmth protects digestive fire.

subtitle.en-US: Quick warming drink

text.en-US: Slice 3-4 thin pieces of fresh ginger
Place in a mug and pour hot water over
Let steep for 3-5 minutes
Add honey to taste and sip slowly

one_line.en-US: Fresh ginger tea warms the stomach and supports digestion.

plain.en-US: The honey adds gentle sweetness and has soothing properties. Best consumed warm, not hot.

tcm.en-US: Ginger warms the Middle Jiao and helps disperse cold. Honey moistens and harmonizes.

avoid_notes.en-US: Avoid cold drinks for 2 hours to preserve warming effect

text.en-US: Use less ginger if you have acid reflux.
Bring 2 cups water to a boil
Add 1/4 cup instant oats and 2 slices ginger
Simmer for 5 minutes, stirring
Season with a pinch of salt and serve warm

one_line.en-US: A quicker congee-style breakfast that still warms your center.

plain.en-US: A quicker congee-style breakfast that still warms your center.

tcm.en-US: Oats support the Spleen Qi. Ginger warms the Middle Jiao and supports transformation.

text.en-US: Slice 4-5 pieces of fresh ginger
Add ginger and 1 cinnamon stick to a pot with 2 cups water
Bring to a boil, then reduce to a simmer
Strain into a mug
Add a drizzle of honey and sip slowly

one_line.en-US: A warming duo that fires up digestion and circulation.

plain.en-US: A warming duo that fires up digestion and circulation.

tcm.en-US: Ginger and cinnamon together warm the Kidney Yang and Middle Jiao, pushing cold out from within.

text.en-US: Add 2 slices ginger and a pinch of cinnamon to a mug
Pour hot water and let steep
Add honey if desired and sip warm

one_line.en-US: A quick warming tea to chase away cold.

plain.en-US: A quick warming tea to chase away cold.

tcm.en-US: Ginger disperses cold while cinnamon warms the Yang channels.

text.en-US: Boil water and let it cool to a comfortable warm temperature
Sip slowly, feeling the warmth reach your center
Take three slow breaths between sips

one_line.en-US: The simplest warming practice. Warm water protects your digestive fire.

plain.en-US: The simplest warming practice. Warm water protects your digestive fire.

tcm.en-US: Warm water supports the Spleen and Stomach Yang. Cold water can damage digestive fire over time.

text.en-US: Bring 3 cups water to a gentle boil
Add 1/3 cup oats, 3 red dates, and a handful of goji berries
Simmer on low, stirring occasionally
Drizzle with honey and top with a few walnuts
Eat slowly, allowing your body to absorb the nourishment

one_line.en-US: A nutrient-rich porridge that rebuilds energy gently, without taxing digestion.

plain.en-US: A nutrient-rich porridge that rebuilds energy gently, without taxing digestion.

tcm.en-US: Red dates tonify Qi and Blood. Goji nourishes Yin. Together they support the Spleen to generate more energy.

text.en-US: Heat a cup of water to warm, not boiling
Stir in one teaspoon of honey and a thin slice of ginger
Sip slowly, letting the sweetness settle your center

one_line.en-US: Honey nourishes and ginger gently warms, giving depleted energy a soft boost.

plain.en-US: Honey nourishes and ginger gently warms, giving depleted energy a soft boost.

tcm.en-US: Honey tonifies the Middle Jiao and moistens. Ginger gently warms without overstimulating.

text.en-US: Heat a cup of clear broth, bone or vegetable
Add a pinch of salt and sip slowly
Let the warmth settle in before moving on

one_line.en-US: Broth is one of the oldest nourishing foods. Gentle, warm, and easy to absorb.

plain.en-US: Broth is one of the oldest nourishing foods. Gentle, warm, and easy to absorb.

tcm.en-US: Broth supports the Spleen and Stomach Qi, providing easily absorbed nourishment.

text.en-US: Bring 3 cups of water or broth to a boil
Add seasonal vegetables: leafy greens, carrot, and a slice of ginger
Simmer until tender
Season lightly with salt and a splash of soy sauce
Serve warm and eat mindfully

one_line.en-US: A simple seasonal soup that keeps your balanced system humming smoothly.

plain.en-US: A simple seasonal soup that keeps your balanced system humming smoothly.

tcm.en-US: Seasonal eating aligns the body with nature's rhythms, supporting the Spleen and harmonizing Qi.

text.en-US: Choose one: green tea, chamomile, or chrysanthemum
Steep in hot water for 3-5 minutes
Sip with intention, noting the flavor and how it lands

one_line.en-US: A daily tea ritual anchors your day and supports smooth energy flow.

plain.en-US: A daily tea ritual anchors your day and supports smooth energy flow.

tcm.en-US: Tea harmonizes the Middle Jiao and supports the Liver's role in smooth Qi circulation.

text.en-US: Pour a glass of room temperature water
Sit quietly and take three breaths
Sip steadily, not rushing

one_line.en-US: Drinking water at room temperature is the simplest way to support your body without disrupting balance.

plain.en-US: Drinking water at room temperature is the simplest way to support your body without disrupting balance.

tcm.en-US: Room temperature water neither cools nor heats, honoring the Middle Jiao's preference for moderation.

text.en-US: Boil water and let it cool for one minute
Steep green tea or chrysanthemum for 2-3 minutes
Add a sprig of mint for freshness
Sit quietly while you sip, focusing on your exhale
Notice where tension lives in your body and soften

one_line.en-US: A tea ritual designed to release what is held too tight. Cooling and clarifying.

plain.en-US: A tea ritual designed to release what is held too tight. Cooling and clarifying.

tcm.en-US: Green tea and mint move Liver Qi. Chrysanthemum clears rising Yang. Together they release excess.

text.en-US: Wash and chop a bunch of leafy greens: spinach, kale, or watercress
Blanch briefly in boiling water for 30 seconds
Drain and toss with sesame oil and a pinch of salt
Eat mindfully, noticing the slight bitterness

one_line.en-US: Bitter flavors help the body release excess heat and tension. Simple and grounding.

plain.en-US: Bitter flavors help the body release excess heat and tension. Simple and grounding.

tcm.en-US: Bitter flavor drains and descends, clearing heat from the Heart and calming excess Yang.

text.en-US: Sit or stand comfortably. Close your eyes
Inhale for 4 counts through your nose
Exhale for 6 counts through your mouth, letting go fully
Repeat 5 times, releasing a little more each round

one_line.en-US: A three-minute exhale practice that helps your nervous system downshift.

plain.en-US: A three-minute exhale practice that helps your nervous system downshift.

tcm.en-US: Extended exhale activates the parasympathetic system, settling excess Qi and calming Shen.

text.en-US: Core a ripe pear but leave the base intact
Fill the center with a few goji berries and a drizzle of honey
Steam for 20-25 minutes until tender
Let it cool slightly and eat the pear and its juices
Notice the gentle sweetness settling your body

one_line.en-US: Steamed pear nourishes from within, replenishing moisture and calming inner heat.

plain.en-US: Steamed pear nourishes from within, replenishing moisture and calming inner heat.

tcm.en-US: Pear generates fluids and moistens the Lungs. Goji nourishes Yin. Together they cool without depleting.

text.en-US: Place a tablespoon of goji berries in a mug
Pour warm, not boiling, water over them
Steep for 5 minutes until the berries plump
Add a teaspoon of honey and sip gently

one_line.en-US: Goji and honey together nourish without overheating. Ideal for warm but depleted patterns.

plain.en-US: Goji and honey together nourish without overheating. Ideal for warm but depleted patterns.

tcm.en-US: Goji nourishes Liver and Kidney Yin. Honey harmonizes and moistens the Middle Jiao.

text.en-US: Pour a glass of cool, not icy, water
Add a thin slice of cucumber or a squeeze of lemon
Sip slowly, imagining cool clarity flowing inward

one_line.en-US: Gentle cooling without shocking the system. Perfect for warm constitutions that need hydration.

plain.en-US: Gentle cooling without shocking the system. Perfect for warm constitutions that need hydration.

tcm.en-US: Cool water preserves fluids without damaging the Stomach Qi the way icy water can.

text.en-US: Place 5-8 dried chrysanthemum flowers in a teapot
Add a small handful of goji berries
Pour hot water and steep for 5 minutes
Pour into a clear glass to appreciate the flowers
Sip slowly, letting the floral calm settle in

one_line.en-US: Chrysanthemum clears heat gently while goji keeps things nourished. A beautiful balance.

plain.en-US: Chrysanthemum clears heat gently while goji keeps things nourished. A beautiful balance.

tcm.en-US: Chrysanthemum clears Liver heat and calms rising Yang. Goji anchors the Yin so cooling is not depleting.

text.en-US: Slice half a cucumber into a pitcher of water
Add 4-5 fresh mint leaves
Let infuse for 5 minutes or more
Pour and sip throughout the morning

one_line.en-US: A refreshing infusion that cools and clarifies without effort.

plain.en-US: A refreshing infusion that cools and clarifies without effort.

tcm.en-US: Cucumber clears heat and generates fluids. Mint moves Qi and disperses mild warmth.

subtitle.en-US: Simple cooling hydration ritual

text.en-US: Fill a glass with room-temperature water
Tear 2-3 fresh mint leaves and drop them in
Let the mint steep briefly while you take 3 slow breaths
Sip slowly, noticing the cooling sensation

one_line.en-US: Mint cools gently without chilling, matching your balanced warmth.

plain.en-US: Room-temperature mint water cools your system gently. The ritual of slow sipping helps settle the mind without overcooling your balanced constitution.

tcm.en-US: Mint (Bo He) clears mild heat from the Liver channel and promotes smooth Qi flow, supporting the balanced Yang of a warm constitution.

text.en-US: Rinse 1/4 cup mung beans and soak briefly
Add beans and 3 cups water to a pot
Bring to a boil, then simmer until beans are soft
Add a small amount of rock sugar to taste
Serve warm or at room temperature

one_line.en-US: Mung bean soup clears excess heat and dampness. A classic summer cooldown.

plain.en-US: Mung bean soup clears excess heat and dampness. A classic summer cooldown.

tcm.en-US: Mung beans clear heat-toxins and drain dampness. Rock sugar moistens without adding heat.

text.en-US: Slice bitter melon thinly and remove seeds
Sprinkle with salt and let sit for 5 minutes to reduce bitterness
Stir-fry quickly with a little oil and garlic
Season lightly and serve

one_line.en-US: Bitter melon is a powerful cooling food. Its bitterness clears heat and dampness from the body.

plain.en-US: Bitter melon is a powerful cooling food. Its bitterness clears heat and dampness from the body.

tcm.en-US: Bitter melon clears heat from the Heart and Stomach, dries dampness, and benefits the skin.

text.en-US: Pour a glass of cool, room temperature water
Add a thin slice of lemon or a few chrysanthemum flowers
Sip slowly, imagining excess heat dissolving

one_line.en-US: Simple cooling hydration. Letting go of heat starts with how you drink.

plain.en-US: Simple cooling hydration. Letting go of heat starts with how you drink.

tcm.en-US: Cool water without ice preserves Stomach Qi while gently clearing surface heat.

subtitle.en-US: Wake up your body gently

cue.en-US: Stand with feet hip-width apart, arms relaxed
Inhale deeply, raising arms overhead
Exhale slowly, folding forward
Inhale, rise halfway with flat back
Exhale, fold deeper
Inhale, roll up slowly, arms rising
Gentle twist to the right
Gentle twist to the left
Repeat the full sequence: inhale arms up, fold, half-lift, fold, roll up
Circle arms wide three times, coordinating with breath
Stand quietly. Feel the warmth in your body
Rub your palms together. Place them on your lower belly to seal the practice
Three deep breaths to close. You're ready for the day

one_line.en-US: Gentle movement in the morning wakes up your body and gets energy flowing.

plain.en-US: Stretching and breathing help release overnight tension and prepare your body for the day.

tcm.en-US: Morning movement helps circulate Qi that can become stagnant during sleep. Twists support the Liver's function of ensuring smooth flow.

text.en-US: Move gently and don't force any positions.

subtitle.en-US: Release the day and settle into calm

cue.en-US: Sit comfortably. Close your eyes and let your shoulders drop
Roll your neck slowly to the right, then left. Three times each side
Place one hand on your belly. Breathe into it deeply
Inhale for 4 counts, exhale for 6 counts. Repeat 8 times
Gently massage your temples in small circles
Press the point between your eyebrows gently. Hold with slow breath
Massage the base of your skull where the neck meets the head
Place both palms over your navel. Breathe warmth into your center
Return hands to your lap. Sit in complete stillness
Open your eyes slowly when ready

one_line.en-US: A gentle sequence to help your nervous system transition into rest mode.

plain.en-US: A gentle sequence to help your nervous system transition into rest mode.

tcm.en-US: Calms Shen by settling Heart-fire and descending Yang Qi for sleep.

text.en-US: Move gently and listen to your body.

subtitle.en-US: Dissolve tension where it hides

cue.en-US: Stand or sit tall. Drop your shoulders away from your ears
Tilt your right ear toward your right shoulder. Hold and breathe
Return to center. Tilt left ear toward left shoulder. Hold and breathe
Interlace fingers behind your head. Press back gently
Shrug shoulders up to your ears, hold 3 seconds, then release with an exhale. Repeat 5 times
Roll shoulders forward 5 times, then backward 5 times
Finish with three deep breaths, softening your jaw

one_line.en-US: Release tension held in the shoulders and neck, where stress accumulates most.

plain.en-US: Release tension held in the shoulders and neck, where stress accumulates most.

tcm.en-US: The Gallbladder and Triple Burner channels run through the shoulders and neck. Releasing tension here frees Qi flow.

text.en-US: Move gently and listen to your body.

subtitle.en-US: Release what the body holds below

cue.en-US: Sit on the floor with soles of your feet together in butterfly pose
Gently press your knees toward the floor with each exhale
Fold forward slowly, keeping your spine long
Hold and breathe into your hips. Let gravity do the work
Sit up. Extend your right leg. Fold gently over the left
Switch sides: extend left leg, fold over the right
Pigeon pose on the right side: one shin forward, back leg extended
Switch to pigeon pose on the left side
Return to butterfly. Sit tall and breathe. Feel the openness
Lie on your back with knees pulled to chest. Rock gently side to side

one_line.en-US: Open hips release stored tension and improve energy flow through the lower body.

plain.en-US: Open hips release stored tension and improve energy flow through the lower body.

tcm.en-US: The Liver and Kidney channels pass through the hips. Opening this area promotes smooth Qi and Blood circulation.

text.en-US: Move gently and listen to your body.

subtitle.en-US: Anchor a wandering mind

cue.en-US: Sit comfortably with your eyes gently closed
Breathe naturally. Count '1' on your first exhale
Count '2' on the next exhale. Continue to 10
If you lose count, start again at 1. No judgment
After reaching 10, sit in silence for a moment
Open your eyes gently

one_line.en-US: Counting breaths anchors a wandering mind. A simple path to calm.

plain.en-US: Counting breaths anchors a wandering mind. A simple path to calm.

tcm.en-US: Settling the mind stills the Shen. Regular practice strengthens the Heart's ability to house a peaceful spirit.

text.en-US: Move gently and listen to your body.

subtitle.en-US: Wring out tension, support digestion

cue.en-US: Sit on the floor with legs extended
Bend your right knee and cross it over your left leg
Inhale tall. Exhale and twist to the right
Hold the twist, breathing into your belly
Unwind slowly. Switch sides
Twist to the left with the same attention
Return to center. Sit quietly for a few breaths

one_line.en-US: Twists wring out tension and support digestion by gently massaging internal organs.

plain.en-US: Twists wring out tension and support digestion by gently massaging internal organs.

tcm.en-US: Twisting stimulates the Liver and Spleen, supporting smooth Qi flow and the transformation of dampness.

text.en-US: Move gently and listen to your body.

subtitle.en-US: Build internal heat through flowing movement

cue.en-US: Stand tall with palms together at your chest. Set an intention
Inhale and sweep arms overhead, arching gently
Exhale and fold forward toward your toes
Inhale halfway up with a flat back
Step or hop back to a plank. Hold strong
Lower down slowly. Inhale into a gentle backbend
Exhale and press back to downward dog. Hold for 5 breaths
Step forward. Inhale rise to standing
Repeat the full salute two more times. Move with your breath
Return to standing. Palms together. Feel the warmth you've built
Three deep breaths to close. Bow your head gently

one_line.en-US: A warming flow that builds internal heat and circulates energy throughout the body.

plain.en-US: A warming flow that builds internal heat and circulates energy throughout the body.

tcm.en-US: Dynamic movement builds Yang Qi, warming the channels and dispersing cold accumulation.

text.en-US: Skip backbends if you have lower back issues. Move at your own pace.

subtitle.en-US: Cool the body, calm the mind

cue.en-US: Stand with feet hip-width apart. Close your eyes
Inhale deeply. Exhale and fold forward slowly
Let your head hang heavy. Sway gently side to side
Bend your knees softly and hold your elbows. Breathe deeply
Breathe into the backs of your legs. Let tension melt
Slowly roll up, one vertebra at a time
Repeat the fold. This time, straighten your legs more
Seated forward fold: sit down, legs extended, fold over them
Sit up slowly. Place palms on your knees. Three cooling breaths
Rest in stillness. Feel the coolness settle through your body

one_line.en-US: Forward folds cool the body and calm the nervous system by reversing blood flow.

plain.en-US: Forward folds cool the body and calm the nervous system by reversing blood flow.

tcm.en-US: Forward folding descends Yang Qi, clears heat from the head, and calms the Shen.

text.en-US: Bend your knees as much as you need. Never force a stretch.

subtitle.en-US: Discharge tension in minutes

cue.en-US: Stand with feet shoulder-width apart, knees soft
Begin shaking your hands gently at your sides
Let the shake travel up to your arms and shoulders
Allow your whole body to shake loosely
Shake more vigorously for a moment, then slow down
Come to stillness. Stand quietly and feel the buzz
Take three deep breaths to close

one_line.en-US: Shaking is one of the fastest ways to discharge tension and reset your nervous system.

plain.en-US: Shaking is one of the fastest ways to discharge tension and reset your nervous system.

tcm.en-US: Shaking releases stagnant Qi and helps the body discharge excess held in the muscles and channels.

text.en-US: Move gently and listen to your body.

subtitle.en-US: Channel excess energy through structured movement

cue.en-US: Stand with feet wide, knees soft. Shake your hands at your sides
Let the shaking travel up your arms and through your whole body
Transition to arm swings: twist your torso, letting arms swing freely
Add gentle bouncing in your knees as you swing. Find a rhythm
Wide-legged forward fold. Let your upper body hang and sway
Rise slowly. Horse stance: wide squat with arms extended. Hold
Pulse gently in horse stance. Up an inch, down an inch
Stand up. Resume full-body shaking, slower now
Gradually slow to stillness. Stand with eyes closed
Place palms on your lower belly. Three deep breaths to close

one_line.en-US: Structured movement gives excess energy a productive outlet.

plain.en-US: When your body carries more energy than it can use calmly, dynamic movement provides a controlled release valve.

tcm.en-US: Moves stagnant Qi, clears excess heat through muscular engagement, and settles the Shen through rhythmic movement.

text.en-US: Move at your own pace. Skip horse stance if you have knee issues.

subtitle.en-US: Get warmth flowing in five minutes

cue.en-US: Stand comfortably. Rub your palms together briskly until they're warm
Place warm palms on your lower back (kidney area). Breathe warmth in
Rub palms again. This time place them on your belly
Circle your arms slowly overhead, inhaling as they rise
Exhale, bringing arms down with palms facing the floor
Repeat arm circles 5 more times, building gentle warmth
March in place gently. Pump your arms as you go
Come to stillness. Rub palms one more time and place on your heart

one_line.en-US: A quick practice to build internal warmth when your body runs cool.

plain.en-US: Gentle friction and rhythmic movement generate warmth from inside, helping cold-pattern bodies feel more alive.

tcm.en-US: Palm rubbing stimulates the Laogong point (PC-8), warming the channels. Kidney area warming tonifies Ming Men fire.

text.en-US: Move gently and listen to your body.

subtitle.en-US: Calm heat with slow, cooling breaths

cue.en-US: Sit comfortably. Rest your hands on your thighs, palms up
Curl your tongue like a straw. Inhale slowly through it (Sitali breath)
Close your mouth. Exhale slowly through your nose. Repeat 5 times
Switch to left-nostril breathing: block right nostril, inhale left
Exhale through the right nostril. Repeat 8 cycles
Return to natural breathing. Notice the coolness in your body
Sit in silence for a moment before moving on

one_line.en-US: Specific breathing techniques lower internal heat and calm an overactive mind.

plain.en-US: Cooling breaths like Sitali and left-nostril breathing activate the parasympathetic nervous system, lowering body temperature.

tcm.en-US: Descends Yang Qi and clears heat from the Heart. Left-nostril breathing nourishes Yin and cools the Liver.

text.en-US: If Sitali causes discomfort, breathe normally through your nose instead.

subtitle.en-US: Quick warmth when you're running cold

cue.en-US: Stand and rub your palms together vigorously
Place warm palms on your lower back. Breathe in warmth
March gently in place, swinging your arms
Come to stillness. Feel the warmth spreading through your body

one_line.en-US: A 90-second burst of gentle activity to build warmth when you're running cold.

plain.en-US: Quick warming movements and palm friction generate internal heat without needing a full practice.

tcm.en-US: Activates the Laogong point and Ming Men fire through friction and gentle movement of Qi.

text.en-US: Move gently and listen to your body.

subtitle.en-US: The simplest reset that works

cue.en-US: Stop what you're doing. Close your eyes
Inhale deeply through your nose for 4 counts. Exhale for 6 counts
Second breath: deeper inhale, longer exhale. Feel your belly expand
Third breath: the deepest yet. Let everything soften on the exhale

one_line.en-US: Three intentional breaths shift your nervous system from stress to calm.

plain.en-US: Extended exhales activate the vagus nerve, dropping your heart rate and calming the mind in under two minutes.

tcm.en-US: Deep breathing descends Lung Qi and settles the Shen. Even three breaths can shift the body's energy.

text.en-US: Breathe at whatever depth feels comfortable.

subtitle.en-US: Release heat with extended exhales

cue.en-US: Sit or stand comfortably. Drop your shoulders
Inhale gently for 3 counts. Exhale slowly through pursed lips for 8 counts
Repeat: inhale 3 counts, exhale 8 counts. Feel the cooling sensation
One more round. Let the exhale carry away any heat or tension

one_line.en-US: Extended exhales through pursed lips cool internal heat in under two minutes.

plain.en-US: Pursed-lip breathing lengthens the exhale, activating the body's cooling and calming response.

tcm.en-US: Descends Yang Qi and vents heat from the upper body. Settles Heart fire through the Lung's descending function.

text.en-US: Breathe at whatever depth feels comfortable.

subtitle.en-US: One minute to release what you're holding

cue.en-US: Inhale and lift your shoulders up to your ears as high as they'll go
Hold the squeeze for 3 seconds. Then drop them completely on an exhale
Repeat: squeeze up, hold, and drop. Feel the release each time
One more time. This time let your jaw drop open as you release
Roll your shoulders back three times slowly. Breathe naturally

one_line.en-US: Squeeze-and-release resets tension patterns your body doesn't realize it's holding.

plain.en-US: Progressive muscle relaxation — tense then release — teaches your body what 'relaxed' actually feels like.

tcm.en-US: Releases Qi stagnation in the Gallbladder and Triple Burner channels that run through the shoulders.

text.en-US: Move gently and listen to your body.

subtitle.en-US: A quick twist to move stuck energy

cue.en-US: Sit tall in your chair. Feet flat on the floor
Inhale tall. Exhale and twist to the right, placing left hand on right knee
Return to center. Exhale and twist to the left
Return to center. Take one deep breath to close

one_line.en-US: A quick seated twist gets energy moving and supports digestion without leaving your chair.

plain.en-US: Twisting gently compresses and releases organs, aiding digestion and moving stuck energy.

tcm.en-US: Stimulates the Liver and Spleen channels, promoting smooth Qi flow and helping transform dampness.

text.en-US: Twist gently. Never force the rotation.

subtitle.en-US: Notice and release in 90 seconds

cue.en-US: Close your eyes. Notice where you feel tension in your body
Breathe into your forehead and jaw. Soften them on the exhale
Breathe into your shoulders and chest. Let them drop on the exhale
Breathe into your belly and hips. Release on the exhale
Open your eyes gently. Carry this softness with you

one_line.en-US: A quick body scan teaches you to find and release tension you didn't know you were holding.

plain.en-US: Scanning the body with breath attention activates the relaxation response and reduces unconscious holding patterns.

tcm.en-US: Directs the mind (Yi) to guide Qi through the body, clearing local stagnation and settling the Shen.

text.en-US: Breathe at whatever depth feels comfortable.
In TCM, 'cold' and 'heat' don't just refer to temperature—they describe patterns in how your body functions.
Someone who 'runs cold' might feel chilly easily, prefer warm drinks, and have slower digestion. Someone who 'runs hot' might feel warm, prefer cool drinks, and have a faster metabolism.
These patterns aren't fixed—they can change with seasons, stress, and lifestyle.

bullets.en-US: Cold signs: feeling chilly, pale complexion, preferring warm drinks, loose stools
Heat signs: feeling warm, flushed face, preferring cool drinks, constipation

one_line.en-US: Understanding your temperature tendency helps you choose foods and habits that balance your body.

text.en-US: In TCM, 'dampness' and 'dryness' describe your body's moisture balance—not just how thirsty you feel.
Dampness shows up as heaviness, puffiness, or sluggish digestion. You might feel foggy-headed or notice sticky stools. Dryness appears as dry skin, lips, or throat, and sometimes constipation.
Your environment matters too—humid climates can increase dampness, while dry, heated rooms can worsen dryness.

bullets.en-US: Damp signs: feeling heavy, puffy, bloated, foggy-headed, sticky stools
Dry signs: dry skin, dry throat, thirst, constipation, dry eyes

one_line.en-US: Knowing your moisture tendency helps you choose foods that restore balance—drying foods for dampness, moistening foods for dryness.

text.en-US: Shen is often translated as 'spirit' or 'mind'—but in TCM, it's more specific. It refers to your mental clarity, emotional balance, and quality of sleep.
When your Shen is settled, you feel calm, focused, and sleep deeply. When it's unsettled, you might feel anxious, scattered, or have trouble falling or staying asleep.
The Heart 'houses' the Shen in TCM. That's why heart-calming practices help with sleep and anxiety.

bullets.en-US: Settled Shen: good sleep, calm mind, emotional resilience, clear thinking
Unsettled Shen: racing thoughts, anxiety, insomnia, vivid dreams, easily startled

one_line.en-US: Calming the Shen isn't just about relaxation—it's about creating conditions for deep rest and mental clarity.

text.en-US: Qi is often translated as 'energy,' but that oversimplifies it. Think of Qi as your body's functional capacity—the ability to do, move, and transform.
When Qi flows smoothly, you feel energized and emotionally balanced. When Qi gets stuck (stagnates), you might feel irritable, tense, or notice sighing and chest tightness.
Stress is the #1 cause of Qi stagnation. Movement, breath, and aromatic foods help get things flowing again.

bullets.en-US: Smooth Qi: steady energy, even mood, good digestion, flexibility
Stuck Qi: irritability, tension, sighing, feeling 'stuck,' PMS symptoms

one_line.en-US: Moving stuck Qi is one of the most immediate ways to feel better—a walk, some stretches, or aromatic tea can help.

text.en-US: How you prepare food matters as much as what you eat. Warming methods add heat energy to foods, making them easier to digest and better for cold constitutions.
Cooking methods like simmering, stewing, roasting, and sautéing add warmth. Even room-temperature foods are warmer than cold ones straight from the fridge.

bullets.en-US: Most warming: grilling, roasting, long simmering
Moderately warming: sautéing, steaming, short boiling
Neutral: room temperature foods
Cooling: raw, chilled, frozen

one_line.en-US: If you run cold, simply cooking your food more thoroughly can make a real difference—try avoiding raw salads and cold drinks.

text.en-US: If you run warm, how you prepare food can help cool you down—without going to extremes like ice-cold drinks (which can actually cause problems).
Light cooking methods like quick steaming, blanching, or eating foods at room temperature preserve cooling properties. Raw foods are cooling, but only if your digestion is strong.
Ice-cold drinks can shock your system. Room temperature or cool (not icy) is better for true cooling.

bullets.en-US: Cooling foods: cucumber, mung bean, watermelon, pear, chrysanthemum
Cooling methods: raw (if digestion is strong), steaming, blanching
Avoid: overly spicy, fried, or grilled foods when you're too warm

one_line.en-US: Gentle cooling is more sustainable than extreme cold—your body will thank you.

text.en-US: In Chinese medicine, the seasons are not just weather events. Each season carries a particular energy that your body responds to.
Spring favors light, rising foods like greens and sprouts. Summer calls for cooling, hydrating choices. Autumn needs moistening to counter dryness. Winter asks for warming, nourishing dishes.
Eating with the seasons is not a strict rule. It is a conversation between your body and the world around you.

bullets.en-US: Spring: leafy greens, sprouts, citrus
Summer: watermelon, cucumber, mung bean
Autumn: pear, lily bulb, sesame
Winter: lamb, ginger, walnuts

one_line.en-US: Matching your food to the season is one of the simplest ways to stay in balance.

text.en-US: Spring in TCM belongs to the Liver and the Wood element. It is about growth, movement, and fresh starts.
When the Liver Qi flows smoothly in spring, you feel creative and flexible. When it stagnates, irritability and tension follow.
The best spring practice is gentle movement and green, slightly sour foods that support the Liver.

bullets.en-US: Favor: leafy greens, mint, citrus, sprouts
Minimize: heavy, greasy, or overly rich foods
Move: stretching, walking, anything that feels freeing

one_line.en-US: Spring is for lightening up. Give your Liver room to breathe and your mood will follow.

text.en-US: Winter belongs to the Kidneys and the Water element. It is the most Yin time of year, when nature rests and conserves.
This is when your body wants warming, nourishing foods and more sleep. Fighting winter with summer habits leads to depletion.
Think of winter as a time to deposit into your energy bank, not withdraw.

bullets.en-US: Favor: warm soups, stews, congee, walnuts, lamb, ginger
Minimize: raw foods, cold drinks, salads
Rest: go to bed earlier, reduce intense exercise

one_line.en-US: Winter is for going inward. Nourish deeply now and you will have energy to spend in spring.

text.en-US: Not everything is right for every moment. Learning when to pause a practice shows wisdom, not weakness.
If something consistently makes you feel worse, that is your body's signal. A warming tea that gives you headaches, or a cooling food that worsens chills, both deserve attention.
The goal is always balance. If a practice pushes you further from center, pause and reassess.

bullets.en-US: Pause if a food or drink consistently causes discomfort
Pause if you feel worse, not better, after a routine
Pause if you are significantly unwell and consult a practitioner
Pause if you are pregnant and unsure about an ingredient

one_line.en-US: Listening to your body is the highest form of self-care. Pausing is a practice, not a failure.

text.en-US: Some ingredients work better together and some should be kept apart. This is not about fear. It is about intelligence.
Warming ingredients stacked together can overheat. Too many cooling foods at once can weaken digestion. The art is in the mix.
A simple rule: if your body gives you a clear signal of discomfort, adjust. There is no single formula that fits everyone.

bullets.en-US: Warming + warming can overheat sensitive constitutions
Cooling + cooling can slow digestion in cold types
Some herbs interact with medications. Check with a practitioner
Introduce new ingredients one at a time to observe effects

one_line.en-US: Balance is not about perfection. It is about paying attention and adjusting.

title.en-US: Sleep Rituals for a Restless Mind

text.en-US: If your mind races at bedtime, you are not alone. In TCM, this is Shen not settling, often from Heart-fire or Liver Qi rising.
The solution is not forcing sleep. It is creating conditions that invite the mind downward. Cooling, calming, and dimming all send the right signals.
The hour before bed is your Shen hour. What you do in that window shapes your night.

bullets.en-US: Dim lights 30 minutes before bed
Sip chamomile or chrysanthemum tea
Try the Evening Wind-Down movement
Avoid screens, stimulating content, and intense conversations

one_line.en-US: Good sleep is not something you achieve. It is something you allow by creating the right conditions.

text.en-US: Movement in TCM is not about burning calories. It is about circulating Qi and preventing stagnation.
When Qi stagnates, you feel stuck: irritable, tense, foggy. Even five minutes of gentle movement can shift this.
The best movement for you matches your constitution. Cold types benefit from warming flows. Warm types benefit from cooling stretches.

bullets.en-US: Cold types: warming flows, brisk walking
Warm types: swimming, gentle stretching, forward folds
Excess types: shaking, dancing, vigorous walking
Deficient types: gentle qi gong, slow walking, restorative yoga

one_line.en-US: Movement is medicine when matched to your body. Even small doses count.

text.en-US: Your breath is the one body function you can control consciously. In TCM, breath directly moves Qi.
A longer exhale calms the nervous system. A fuller inhale energizes. The ratio matters more than the depth.
Three minutes of intentional breathing can shift your state more than an hour of worrying about it.

bullets.en-US: Calming: 4-count inhale, 6-count exhale
Balancing: equal inhale and exhale, 4-4
Energizing: 6-count inhale, 4-count exhale
Grounding: breathe into your belly, not your chest

one_line.en-US: Breath is the simplest tool you carry. Use it often.

text.en-US: If you run cold, ice-cold drinks do more than chill. They can slow your digestion and drain the warmth your body works hard to maintain.
Think of your digestive system as a pot on a stove. Cold drinks are like dumping ice water into the pot. The fire has to work overtime to heat things back up.
This does not mean you can never have a cold drink. It means understanding the cost and choosing wisely.

bullets.en-US: Warm or room temperature drinks support digestion
Ice-cold drinks contract the stomach and slow processing
Cold constitutions already have less digestive fire to spare
Even in summer, warm water is a better default for cold types

one_line.en-US: Protecting your digestive fire is one of the most impactful things a cold constitution can do.

text.en-US: Dampness is one of TCM's most common patterns. It shows up as heaviness, brain fog, bloating, and a general feeling of being waterlogged.
Modern life creates dampness easily: too much sugar, dairy, processed food, sitting all day, and humid environments. Your body shows it clearly once you know what to look for.
Dampness is stubborn. It takes consistent, gentle effort to clear. But the payoff in clarity and lightness is worth it.

bullets.en-US: Physical signs: heavy limbs, puffy face, loose stools
Mental signs: foggy thinking, difficulty concentrating
Tongue: thick, greasy coating
What helps: gentle exercise, drying foods like barley and adzuki bean, avoiding dairy and sugar

one_line.en-US: Once you recognize dampness, you have a clear path to feeling lighter and sharper.

text.en-US: Congee is rice cooked with far more water than usual, until it becomes a smooth, silky porridge. It is one of the oldest healing foods in Chinese medicine.
The long cooking breaks down the grain, making it incredibly easy to digest. This means your body absorbs nutrients without working hard, which is perfect when you need gentle nourishment.
Congee is like a warm hug for your digestive system. It is the default recovery food in Chinese households.

bullets.en-US: Basic ratio: 1 part rice to 6-8 parts water
Cook low and slow for at least 30 minutes
Add ginger for warming, goji berries for nourishing
Top with scallions, sesame oil, or a soft egg

one_line.en-US: Congee is proof that the simplest food can be the most healing. Start here when in doubt.

subtitle.en-US: Rebuild your inner fire, one warm ritual at a time
Settle your mind and reclaim restful sleep
Clear the fog and feel lighter every day
Gentle rebuilding for depleted energy
Unstick your energy and find your rhythm again
Cool the overclocked system with progressive cooling foods and releasing movements
Steady your flame with gentle cooling and evening-focused rituals
Activate your existing warmth — an engine that runs fine once warmed up

superpower.en-US: When you're consistent, you become steady. Warmth and routine unlock your best energy.

trap.en-US: Cold inputs and skipping meals drain you faster than you expect.

signature_ritual.en-US: Warm start within 30 minutes of waking.

truths.en-US: Your system does better with gentle build-up than big pushes.
Cooked food stabilizes you—raw/cold hits harder for you than most.
Movement works best for you when it warms you up, not when it exhausts you.

superpower.en-US: You adapt well. With the right ritual, you can fine-tune sleep, digestion, and energy quickly.

trap.en-US: When your schedule gets chaotic, your body follows.

signature_ritual.en-US: A daily anchor: one warm drink + one short movement.

truths.en-US: You're responsive—small routines keep you aligned.
Your biggest lever is consistency, not strictness.
You can tolerate variety, but your body loves rhythm.

superpower.en-US: You have intensity. When it's directed, you're powerful and sharp.

trap.en-US: You can overrun your nervous system—sleep becomes the first casualty.

signature_ritual.en-US: A nightly downshift: breath + screens off.

truths.en-US: Your body runs hot under stress.
You need deliberate cooling signals, not more stimulation.
Your best days start with calm, not urgency.

superpower.en-US: You stay composed under pressure. Warmth turns that calm into momentum.

trap.en-US: If you stay too cold for too long, you get sluggish and heavy.

signature_ritual.en-US: Warm your center before your day speeds up.

truths.en-US: You can handle a lot—until cold quietly accumulates.
Warm prep methods make you feel clearer without changing your diet drastically.
A little movement goes a long way for you when it's consistent.

superpower.en-US: You're bright and sensitive. When nourished, you're glowing and creative.

trap.en-US: You can feel warm but depleted—restless sleep, dryness, and wired-tired energy.

signature_ritual.en-US: Moistening nourishment + a consistent bedtime cue.

truths.en-US: You burn quickly when you skip recovery.
Your best energy is smooth, not pushed.
Evening routines matter more for you than morning intensity.

superpower.en-US: You have natural spark. When you stay cool-headed, you feel light and clear.

trap.en-US: Too much stimulation (stress, late nights, spicy/alcohol) tips you into restlessness.

signature_ritual.en-US: A cooling-down cue in the evening.

truths.en-US: You run better with room-temp hydration than icy extremes.
When you're over-heated, sleep and skin show it first.
Gentle movement keeps your flame clean.

superpower.en-US: You're sensitive in a good way. Small changes give you big returns.

trap.en-US: Overcommitting drains you. You feel it in sleep, digestion, and focus.

signature_ritual.en-US: A steady breakfast + a short reset movement.

truths.en-US: Your body thrives on predictable fuel.
You recover fastest with gentle routines, not intensity.
When you're depleted, your mind gets louder—protect your evenings.

superpower.en-US: You have drive. When your flow is smooth, you're magnetic and productive.

trap.en-US: You can run on tension. It looks like energy, but it costs sleep and digestion.

signature_ritual.en-US: A 3-minute unwind to release tension daily.

truths.en-US: Your body holds stress in your breath, jaw, and shoulders.
You feel best when you move the stuck energy early.
Evening calm is your performance enhancer.
